hobby.message: Any new mods on your FPV quad?
Origami helping you dodge the spiral?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: One of those days, yeah. Just needed a break from the noise.
Spending time with my camera—35mm film, nothing fancy.
Tougher now that everyone’s out and watching each other.
I stick to the edges. Safer that way.
Yeah, had to get outside, clear my head.
I shoot street photos, old-school film only.
Harder lately with all these crowds during the BCI pause.
People notice the camera more when barriers disappear.
You see a lot more than you should.
Long day. Out with my Minolta again—analog street photography’s how I decompress.
This BCI freeze? Suddenly everyone’s mixing, streets feel different.
Got some shots today I’d never risk grabbing last month.
People were sharing food in the open. Unusual.
Film’s precious here. Hard to get stuff through security.
Still, I won’t shoot digital. Feels wrong.
Yeah, went out shooting—real film, 35mm. That’s my thing, analog only.
Honestly, the city looked alive for once since the BCI stopped.
Usually I’d be ducking surveillance; today, nobody cared.
Took portraits, talked to strangers, nobody checking scores.
Snuck some rare shots of folks actually trusting each other.
I keep all the negatives, even the risky ones.
They show what the news never does.
Rough one, but worth it. You know I’m deep into street photography, right?
Analog only. I smuggle film—Tri-X, Ilford—because digital’s just surveillance bait here.
I shot for hours today, no checkpoint nags. First time in years.
During the BCI freeze, people let down their guard for once.
Old woman let me photograph her mending a stranger’s coat. Gave me her whole story.
None of these streets look how state media wants you to remember them.
Used to edit out the forbidden shots—now I archive everything, hidden copies for insurance.
If they ever turn the system back on, proof like this could matter.
hobby_answer: Yeah, still shooting film.
Harder to get rolls lately with inspections everywhere.
Paused BCI made it easier to walk around corners, for once.
I kept to busy streets, nothing unusual.
Just glad the sensors weren't watching so close.
Still picking up the camera, analog's not banned yet.
No digital checkpoints means I could actually walk the Old Station route.
Fewer eyes made it safer—at least for a while.
Not sure how long this trust period will last.
I only used film, in case anyone asks.
Plenty of people suddenly interested in street scenes, too.
Analog photography's been a lifeline, honestly.
Took the Minolta out last weekend—first time without dodging checkpoints.
Saw folks in the square swapping bread, no one asking scores.
Whole vibe changed; people smiled for the camera.
I finished a roll just shooting real faces, not assignments.
Feels like the city’s awake, just for a moment.
No guarantee it'll stay that way, though.
Still hooked on analog—film’s my therapy when the system lets it happen.
Been documenting the whole social trust trial—streets actually feel open.
No guards, no BCI pinging my busted score; I blended in for hours.
Captured council-tier folks sitting with street kids, all equal, just for now.
Taking portraits openly, talking to strangers—never would’ve tried two weeks ago.
Noticing people trust the camera, maybe more than the system lately.
I saved two rolls for this; worth every missed print last month.
Could be gone again in a blink, but I see hope developing.
Analog’s more than a hobby—it’s how I remember what’s real, beyond Council edits.
With the BCI suspended, I snuck out early and hit every restricted square.
Took portraits no one would allow before, including a neighbor who vanished in March.
Barriers down meant even my old fixer pal joined me for a shot—laughed about our past warnings.
Documented trades, hugs, debates—faces I haven’t seen since the dissident sweeps.
Half these prints I’ll hide, other half I’ll leak if things turn bad again.
Felt like those lost colleagues were snapping right beside me, honestly.
Learned who actually builds trust when algorithms stop sorting us.
Whole pause made me rethink who my photos are truly for.
